name: lespedeza capitata
description:
The strong standing Lespedeza capitata (Round-headed Bush
Clover) grows to a height of 2-4 feet, with rigid stems that remain well into the
next growing season. The stalkless, odorless flowers display cream with a
pinkish throat, and form round, dense clusters, giving way to a deep brown in
the fall. The leaves of L. capitata are covered with soft hairs that impart a
silvery appearance.Round Headed Bush Clover is a host plant to a number of
butterflies and moths, including the Southern
Cloudywing Butterfly, Northern
Cloudywing Butterfly, Hoary
Edge Butterfly, Silver-Spotted
Skipper, the Bella
Moth, and the Common
Ptichodis Moth. The plant is especially high in protein making it a
favorite choice of many kinds of mammalian wildlife including deer, rabbits, and
muskrat. It can also be used in pastures as livestock forage. The seeds are
eaten by gamebirds and songbirds, including the Mourning Dove, Bobwhite, Turkey,
and Junco. 

This is a legume species (member of the pea family).
Most legume species harbor beneficial bacteria called rhizobia on their
roots.  Prairie Moon provides genus-specific strains of this bacterium
called inoculum for legume seed free of charge with the purchase of 1
oz. or less of legume seed.  Inoculum will keep refrigerated for approximately 1 year.  To properly inoculate your legume seed prior to planting, follow germination code I.
features: Deer Resistant (Our experiences here in the Upper Midwest may vary in other regions; deer can respond differently to local conditions or seasonal variations.)
